newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian 88 CEO blasts Morrison results.
newsitem.headline: Canadian 88 CEO blasts Morrison results.

text.p: Canadian 88 Energy Corp chief executive Greg Noval said on Thursday that year-end results released on Wednesday by takeover target Morrison Petroleums Ltd were misleading and did nothing to change the company's value.

"Morrison's doing their posturing and we're doing ours, but there's nothing that's changed here," Noval said in a phone interview from Winnipeg, his latest stop in a whirlwind tour to sell his bid to investors.
He said that valuations put forward late last year by Nesbitt Burns, now one of Morrison's financial advisers, showed that the company's stock was fully valued at C$8.
Canadian 88 has bid C$10 cash, to a maximum of C$140 million, or 1.5 of its shares for each Morrison share. The hostile offer is valued at C$652 million.
"I venture to say that if we withdrew our bid, the stock would be back at eight bucks," Noval said.
Morrison on Thursday was up 0.25 to C$10.55 in Toronto, a 52-week high, after announcing record financials on Wednesday and disclosing interest from other potential bidders.

Noval disputed Morrison's disclosure that its finding and development costs dropped to as low as C$3.88 a barrel of oil equivalent of proven reserves and C$2.13 per BOE of proven plus probable reserves.
"That's not accurate at all," he said. "Actually, we've just gone over it with our (chartered accountant) and analyzed it and it works out to nine bucks."
He also said that Morrison was taking financial credit for proceeds from asset sales that had yet to be completed.

In the fourth quarter, Morrison entered into deals to sell non-core oil and gas properties for proceeds of C$77 million. It also said on Wednesday it would close its new royalty trust, based on cash flow from an Alberta gas plant and British Columbia oil pipeline, next week for proceeds of C$180 million.

"It's our understanding that these transactions are all effective in January, so they are sort of announcing reserves, production and numbers that they now don't have," Noval said, adding he believed much of Morrison's sharply higher cash flow and earnings in 1996 resulted from higher commodity prices.
"I don't think they're leveling with their shareholders."
Noval said he believed that talk about potential white knights in the wings for Morrison was little more than speculation.

"It's just some arbitrage guys playing around with their stock," he said. "We've had 30 meetings in Canada last week and 25 so far this week, mostly in the U.S., and our offer is being very well received.
